reviewText:
Oh those amnesia stories…how much I loath them. To me, those storylines are a total copout of trying to tell a suspenseful plot by ‘discovering’ your past. Yet some have done a reasonable job like Stalker and XIII. This game Reversion – The Escape is a difficult one to state whether this amnesia copout plotline holds up as it forms part of a trilogy. Being the first one, there’s not much to say as your main goal is to escape the hospital and because it only last one hour, its best-selling point is that it’s free, and there’s nothing wrong with that unless you want to continue on with the saga then you have to pay for them (I think it’s around $AUD 6 each).

The game plays out as your typical point and click adventure game. Double left click to get the menu where you can talk / grab or examine or right click to access your inventory. You can also join items by dragging / dropping two items to make a third and some items are simply red herrings. So there’s nothing new presented here as far as adventure games are concerned.

The puzzles presented are not challenging at all as the clues are quite obvious. Examples like ‘…for the moment’ triggers that you are missing some sort of action and so forth. Also there’s not a lot happening as it plays on one event leads on to another so you won’t be juggling many puzzles in one go. Thankfully the puzzles are all logical so it shouldn’t be too difficult to resolve them. Just examine and talk to everyone and you cannot fail.

The game advertises that it plays homage to the old school adventure games. You can see this via the visuals as it all renders in 2D and actually does look nice. The character’s walking animation are quite stiff however you won’t be suffering from pixel hunting here. The musical scores are very pleasant to hear with sombre scores when doing some investigations and the title screen has an upbeat tempo. Sometimes I wonder if the game is an afterthought from the music itself. The voice acting is pretty decent too yet it has its odd moments of that ‘emotionless’ speech however nothing to cringe about.

Because this game is free, you cannot argue how good / bad it is however because it forms part of a trilogy, I guess you can say you are getting an entrée before the main course. Yet the strongest feature for any adventure game is its storytelling however there’s nothing really thrilling about this one. If developers 3f interactive can pull it off with the next two and increase the length, then it would be a decent purchase overall. However time will tell if this is the case and as for me, the game wasn’t thrilling at all yet enjoyable enough to finish it off with all sixteen achievements earned.

5 / 10

reviewText:
I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone and here are a few of the reasons:
- The puzzles don't make any sense - there's no indication about what you are supposed to do next, so you spend all the time clicking objects around the room randomly, picking them up for a later use, without having a clue how they fit in the story. I must say that this is the first game I've played for which I needed to check a guide at almost every step.
- Sometimes you need to repeat the same action several times until it unlocks the next step - which I find very annoying.
- The mouse cursor doesn't change when you hover an object of interest or a person to talk to them. There are options to inspect objects, take them and talk to persons but those are enabled only if you click the right item.
-  The inventory is opened in a separate window that covers almost entirely the game area. Every time you need to use an item from the inventory, you need to select the item, close the screen and only after that use the object with the desired target. I consider this to be a very bad design decision since the objects that are ment to be used together (from the inventory or from the scene) need to be visible all the time.
- There is no option to skip the dialogues.

On a positive note, it's a short game (around 1h of game play) with very easy achievements - in a single walkthrough you can collect all the achievements except one (that requires a second play through); although keep in  mind that some of them are known to be bugged. Nevertheless it's a very easy game to max out for the achievement collectors.

reviewText:
1st: It is only a demo. The following parts will cost you 6 bucks each.

2nd: Keep in mind that there are tons of better adventures out there, for less money.

3rd: This is work in progress and an indie game. It's not close to be finished and never might be. So only invest in the other parts if you can stand cliffhanger for a long time, because every chapter seems to end with one.

+ Professional dubbing...
- ... that seems slightly out of place, mainly because there are no proper background noises. Developer is using  a really annoying background music, it is not befitting the mood/atmosphere.

+ Nicely drawn pictures...
- ... that are soullessly animated.

+ Most objects/npcs have 3 different ways to interact with: talk to, look at, and take/use...
- ... but most of the time you don't need all that options for the game. Clicking them is not entertaining and you have got to use double click, to open the interaction menue.

+ Most riddles have different stages, which need a variety of items or input from other npcs...
- ...sadly you won't get any feedback at all on how to use your items or how to interact with static objects or persons.

+ There is a hint option...
- ... with a cooldown.

Conclusion: This fraction of a game is quite boring. That is quite harsh, bearing in mind that this first chapter is used as advertisment for the steep priced other parts.

You'll probably need more time to download it, than to play it through.

Imho there are two good types of adventures: The funny ones and the ones with tension/ a deep story. This on lacks the entertaining fun, the monumental narrative and an satisfying ending.

The developers should have done their homework, before charging 6 bucks per following episode.

61/100  for this foiled attempt.

At the moment of writing this review it's ​09.15.2014. And now, at this moment, I'm gonna give the game a thumbs up...

Let's first talk about bad stuff, then the good, then I'll try and explain the overall impression and why I've given it positive grade.

The game has many things against it - the voice over is bad. The char's are flat and lifeless, and translation is abysmal with lots of non-sequiturs and seemingly butchered meanings, but which uninterrupted went on to voice actors, to sound mixers, to testers. Easily it could have been done far more satisfactory. The graphics are simple and remind me of late 2000s flash animation style. There is no option for full HD resolution. Even in my full HD full screen, there are black borders, the game doesn't scale up. There's not much music, nor sound effects. UI is clunky with option wheel which has to be pressed for a second to open, and no way to change default function (there's only three - look, talk, use/take) and always use the same click for it.

But what's good with the game? The setting is unique in more than one way - not just that it's set in Argentina, Buenos Aires, but in the future of the city where some cataclysm devastated the city and supposedly made an independent militia controlled city-state of it. Even in this golden age of indie development, it's extremely rare to experience something which isn't centered in standard circle of western culture in adventure games. It's either some traditional western(ised) setting (say US, New Orleans for Gabriel Knight, Paris for Broken Sword), or some extremely exotic setting like dungeons, far future, or jungle temples. Usually it's completely ignored that there are millions, if not billions of people living in some different urban settings which aren't either New York, or, say, far east. This game allows me to experience different culture. So that's a great plus in my books.

The standard adventure gameplay mechanic flows nicely. There is a hint function, so I was never stuck for long. Usage of objects is logical, there's no use brick on tin can to squish it open and then use antique wig to gather the tomato sauce"* nonsense

Although I'm recommending this game, it's a borderline call --- and that, because Chapter One is free.  I found the overall concept and story engaging enough that I went ahead and bought Chapter Two, which is available for six bucks from the publisher's website.  Also, I happen to be a fan of old-school point-and-click adventure games.

However, I have to be honest: the voice-acting is terrible, the animation is mediocre, and the plot is extremely thin.

Reversion was created in Argentina, so what you're getting is a subbed-and-dubbed version (although it does come with numerous language options, which is a plus).  The result is that you have conversations which sound very much like the actors are reading directly off a script, without once hearing each others' lines.  Inflection and tone are painfully awkward at times, and to top it off, it looks like nobody proofread the subtitles, which are rife with basic spelling errors.

The artwork itself is gorgeous, presenting an immersive feeling of post-apocalyptic (at least for Buenos Aires) adventure.  And while the story is, as I said, thin, it's competently presented with no bugs or plot holes.  There's also a built-in hint system which will dole out tips only after some time has passed, requiring you to at least mull things over before trying to cheat your way through the game.

All in all, I give it six Havanas out of ten... it would be seven, had the voice acting and subtitling translations been up to par.

Even in my full HD full screen, there are black borders, the game doesn't scale up. There's not much music, nor sound effects. UI is clunky with option wheel which has to be pressed for a second to open, and no way to change default function (there's only three - look, talk, use/take) and always use the same click for it.

But what's good with the game? The setting is unique in more than one way - not just that it's set in Argentina, Buenos Aires, but in the future of the city where some cataclysm devastated the city and supposedly made an independent militia controlled city-state of it. Even in this golden age of indie development, it's extremely rare to experience something which isn't centered in standard circle of western culture in adventure games. It's either some traditional western(ised) setting (say US, New Orleans for Gabriel Knight, Paris for Broken Sword), or some extremely exotic setting like dungeons, far future, or jungle temples. Usually it's completely ignored that there are millions, if not billions of people living in some different urban settings which aren't either New York, or, say, far east. This game allows me to experience different culture. So that's a great plus in my books.

Reversion: Chapter 1, is the first of many chapters in the game series Reversion, by 3f Interactive. In this game you will be taking on the role of a character who has no memory of his past. All he knows is that mysteriously 20 years seem to have disappeared, and he has no idea what his name is. You will find yourself in a hospital that has seen better days, and it appears that there is a group of mercenaries determined to keep you right where you are.

Graphically I think this game looks solid. The characters all have that unique feel and look. The cast of people you interact with is small, but that doesn't mean that this game falls flat when it comes to variety. Sure this chapter takes place solely in the hospital and you are only going to be able to interact in eight different scenes, but they are all very well crafted, and they look polished. It is also refreshing to see that you are going to be dealing with characters that are not all the same body type of height.

One that I thought was not close to what I would have expected was the voice acting, or should I say the almost monotone variations of voices. It was not the easiest thing to get through, and there was definitely some missing context in some of the conversations. Now I fully understand that this is not a game that was first created for English speaking individuals, and perhaps they didn't have anyone who really knew English grammar all that well, but for an English speaker, it was a bit difficult.

The controls were your average mouse adventure game. You are going to click to move, hold the click to find out what type of interactions you can have with what you have chosen (touch, look, talk). The right mouse button opens up your inventory. There's also a button that kind of looks like a radar screen that when clicked upon will highlight all the objects that you can in some shape or form interact with.

Alright so lets get into this game, you are a person who knows some stuff, but doesn't know the important stuff, such as name, or the actual year. Something big has happened and the city of Buenos Aires is not only in chaos, but it would appear that there is no true leader. You were found unconscious and were brought in for examination and interrogation. You start the game before the second part. Now knowing that this chapter was free I was not expecting much, and to that end when the first chapter did end at the 45 minute mark, I was a little confused but at the same time I let it slide. There was definitely some depth to the game, there was some combining of items to defeat a puzzle or obstacle, I just wish that there was more to this chapter.

So if you are looking to see what those developers outside the US are capable of I would recommend taking a look at this game. If you are looking for an episodic point click adventure game with a strong first chapter, you are going to be left wanting when in one sitting you have already conquered the entire chapter. Sadly because of lack of content I have to give this game a 6.5 out of 10.
